<h1><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'><span style="mso-spacerun:

style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>TC "<span style='font-weight:normal'>Experiments
for the 3rd Week</span>" \f C \l "1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]--><span
style='font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal>Read Ch 2.1.7 for this set of experiments.</p>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'>Objectives<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.1	Objective" \f C \l
"2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo15;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Configuring the bridge/router</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l5 level1 lfo15;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Simple bridge experiment</p>

<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Configuration Procedures for Bridge/Router<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.2	Configuration
Procedures for Bridge/Router" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>In
this section we describe general bridge/router configuration procedures.</p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.1.1<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>Initial Configuration of Bridge/Router<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.2.1	Initial Configuration
of Bridge/Router" \f C \l "3" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>Below, as an
example, we show the initial configuration of the router 1. For more
information on Cisco routers you can go to the online manuals on Cisco’s
website: <span style='mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'>http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/software/ios121/121cgcr/inter_r/index.htm</span>.
All three routers are running s/w version 12.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>Initial configuration of router1<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Initial Router configuration for
the Cisco 2500 Series</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>When you start the router for the
first time you need to configure it. The following is the configuration
procedure for the 2500 router. This is what you see when you turn it on:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='font-family:Tahoma;
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman"'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>System Bootstrap, Version
5.2(8a), RELEASE SOFTWARE</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Copyright (c) 1986-1995 by
Cisco Systems</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>2500 processor with 6144
Kbytes of main memory</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>F3: 7797768+96332+313248 at
0x3000060</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">              </span>Restricted Rights Legend</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Use, duplication, or
disclosure by the Government is</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>subject to restrictions as set
forth in subparagraph</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>(c) of the Commercial Computer
Software - Restricted</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Rights clause at FAR sec.
52.227-19 and subparagraph</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>(c) (1) (ii) of the Rights in
Technical Data and Computer</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Software clause at DFARS sec.
252.227-7013.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">           </span>Cisco Systems, Inc.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">           </span>170 West Tasman Drive</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">           </span>San Jose, California 95134-1706</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Cisco Internetwork Operating
System Software </p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>IOS (tm) 2500 Software
(C2500-J-L), Version 11.2(10a), RELEASE SOFTWARE (fc1)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Copyright (c) 1986-1997 by
Cisco Systems, Inc.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Compiled Tue 02-Dec-97 16:26
by ckralik</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Image text-base: 0x0303EB6C,
data-base: 0x00001000</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Cisco 2500 (68030) processor
(revision L) with 6144K/2048K bytes of memory.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Processor board ID 05523156,
with hardware revision 00000000</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Bridging software.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>SuperLAT software copyright
1990 by Meridian Technology Corp).</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>X.25 software, Version 2.0,
NET2, BFE and GOSIP compliant.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>TN3270 Emulation software.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>2 Ethernet/IEEE 802.3
interface(s)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>2 Serial network interface(s)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>32K bytes of non-volatile
configuration memory.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>8192K bytes of processor board
System flash (Read ONLY)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Notice: NVRAM invalid,
possibly due to write erase.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">         </span>--- System Configuration Dialog ---</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>At any point you may enter a
question mark '?' for help.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Use ctrl-c to abort
configuration dialog at any prompt.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Default settings are in square
brackets '[]'.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Would you like to enter the
initial configuration dialog? [yes]: y</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Would you like to enter basic
management set up [yes/no]: n</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>(<b><u>NOTE</u></b>: If you
type yes here, you will be able to configure each interface individually by
choosing which interface you want to change (“Enter interface name used to
connect to the management network from the above interface summary”. Note that
the table appearing below will have been shown and you choose one of the
interfaces, e.g., Ethernet0). The dialog is fairly similar to what you will see
below, except not all questions are asked and the order of the question is
slightly different.)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>First, would you like to see
the current interface summary? [yes]: y</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Interface<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">              </span>IP-Address<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">      </span>OK? Method Status<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">                </span>Protocol</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Ethernet0<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">              </span>unassigned<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">      </span>NO<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>unset<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>up<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">                    </span>up<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">      </span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Ethernet1<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">              </span>unassigned<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">      </span>NO<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>unset<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>up<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">                    </span>down<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">    </span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Serial0<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">                </span>unassigned<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">      </span>NO<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>unset<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>down<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">                  </span>down<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">    </span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Serial1<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">          </span><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">      </span>unassigned<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">     
</span>NO<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>unset<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>down<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">                  </span>down<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">    </span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Configuring global parameters:</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Enter host name [Router]: router1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>The enable secret is a one-way
cryptographic secret used</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>instead of the enable password
when it exists.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Enter enable secret: ics</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>The enable password is used
when there is no enable secret</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>and when using older software
and some boot images.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Enter enable password: ics</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>(<b><u>NOTE</u></b>: since we
are using the same password the system will prompt you twice for this password
and warn you that you should not use the same password. Ignore and retype the
same password “ics”)</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Enter virtual terminal password: ics</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Configure SNMP Network Management? [yes]: n</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Configure IP? [yes]: </p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>Configure IGRP routing? [yes]: no</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>Configure RIP routing? [no]: </p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Configure bridging? [no]: </p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Do you want to configure
Ethernet0 [yes]:</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Configure IP on this interface? [yes]: </p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>IP address for this interface[130.91.61.3]: 130.91.61.1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>Subnet mask for this interface [255.255.0.0]:255.255.255.0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'>Class B
network 130.91.0.0, 24 subnet bits, mask is /24</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Do you want to configure
Ethernet1 [no]: yes</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Configure IP on this interface? [no]: yes</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>IP address for this interface: 130.91.62.2</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">    </span>Subnet mask for this interface [255.255.0.0]:255.255.255.0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='margin-left:.5in;text-align:justify'>Class B
network 130.91.0.0, 24 subnet bits, mask is /24</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Do you want to configure
Serial0 [no]:</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Do you want to configure
Serial1 [no]:</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>The following configuration
command script was created:</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>hostname router1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>enable secret 5
$1$REqy$.vlByLc7Xi3ulx6bp.8dJ.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>enable password ics</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>line vty 0 4</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>password ics</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no snmp-server</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>ip routing</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no bridge 1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>interface Ethernet0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>ip address 130.91.61.1
255.255.255.0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no mop enabled</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>interface Ethernet1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>ip address 130.91.62.2
255.255.255.0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no mop enabled</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>interface Serial0</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>shutdown</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no ip address</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>interface Serial1</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>shutdown</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>no ip address</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>end</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>[0] Go to IOS command prompt
without saving this configuration</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>[1] Return back to set up
without saving this configuration</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>[2] Save this configuration to
NVRAM and exit</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Building configuration...</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Use the enabled mode
'configure' command to modify this configuration.</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>Press RETURN to get started!</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface
Ethernet0, changed state to up</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface
Ethernet1, changed state to up</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText style='text-align:justify'>%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface Serial0,
changed state to down</p>

<p class=MsoPlainText>%LINK-3-UPDOWN: Interface Serial1, changed state to down<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Unless
you save the configuration changes to NVRAM (Nonvolatile RAM) permanently, the
router will always reboot with the last saved configuration. Below we make
changes to the router configuration and save it to NVRAM. The router will
operate using the new configuration until changed.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Note that if the routers have
been logged onto, then you will no longer see the initial configuration dialog
come up. You will have to get into the privileged_level mode by typing <b>enable</b>
at the router prompt (see section below for more details on enable command). It
will then ask you for the password (“ics”) and then you have to type: <b>setup.
</b>That will get you in the configuration mode and you follow the dialog as
outlined above. Please note that is you answer “<u>no</u>” to any of the
interface configuration questions it will <u>delete</u> whatever entries it had
for that interface prior to the setup command. If you only want to change the
parameters for one of the interfaces, best option is to use the basic
management set-up.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Typing <b>write</b> at the
privileged prompt will save whatever current configuration you have. Please use
write often so as not to lose your settings. Also note that typing |”?” at any
point with a command will give you all the options for that command, e.g., <b>write
?</b>, or <b>bridge ?</b>.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<h3><![if !supportLists]>1.1.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span><![endif]>Bridge/Router Configuration Procedure</h3>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoBodyTextIndent>Move to the router consoles. The system shows the
user-level prompt, which is the router name ending with an angle bracket “
>” as follows:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span>router_name></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>There is also a
privileged-level prompt available to the system administrator. You can enter
the privileged-level by typing <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>enable</b>
:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span>router_name>
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>enable<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span></b>password<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>: ics</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>After entering
the enable password (see configuration notes above for the enable
"secret" password), you will see the privileged-level prompt, which
consists of the router name followed by the “#<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>”</b>, as follows:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span>router_name#</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>You may type <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>write terminal</b> to display the current
configuration. To configure a router, enter<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>
configure</b> at the privileged-level prompt.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:2'>                        </span>router_name#
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>configure</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>When
you enter <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>configure</b>, the router
prompts you for the source of the configuration commands. Since the default is
the terminal, which is our option, just press the<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> return</b> key. The router will then display an explanation of the
editing functions. You can now enter any changes you want to the configuration.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Router1,
router2 and router3 display the following prompts, <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>router1(config)#, router2(config)#</b> and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>router3(config)#</b>, respectively. Now you can type any configuration
command, line by line.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>In
configuration mode, you can do various system-related tasks, for example,
assigning IP addresses to the interfaces, specifying which protocols to
support, etc. Since it is impossible to describe all the configuration commands
here, we will state configuration commands whenever they are needed.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
end the configuration mode, type <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Ctrl-z</b>.
Then hit CR at the next question. You will get the privileged-level prompt.
Please use the <b>write</b> command to save your settings.<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>You can examine your configuration by typing
<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>write terminal</b>. Enter the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>disable</b> command to return to the
user-level prompt. For more information on the configuration commands, refer to
the router manuals online at:<span style='mso-bidi-font-family:Arial'> http://www.cisco.com/univercd/cc/td/doc/product/software/ios121/121cgcr/inter_r/index.htm</span></p>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.2<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Simple Bridge Experiment<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.3	Simple Bridge
Experiment" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.4in;text-align:justify'>For this
experiment we will only be using two PCs and one router acting as a bridge.
They are connected as shown in figure 2.1 and table 2.1. <b><u>Note</u></b>
that the subnet mask for this experiment is: 255.255.192.0. <b><u>Please note</u></b>
that you need to use either a hub to connect the PCs to the bridge/router or a
cross connect cable. You cannot just use a regular 10baseT cable (straight
thru).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.5in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Table 2.1:<span
style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>IP addresses for Figure 2.1<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.0in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
.5in'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><!--[if gte vml 1]><v:shapetype

<p class=MsoNormal align=center style='text-align:center'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:1.5in;text-align:justify'><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>Figure 2.1:<span style="mso-spacerun:
yes">  </span>Using a transparent bridge<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Figure
2.1 shows the simple case of a bridge configuration, which consists of two
network segments connected by a bridge. (A bridge can also be used to connect
two networks with different subnet IDs.<span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> 
</span>If you want to connect 135.88.128.0 net and 135.88.64.0 net using a
bridge, as an example, every PC in both subnets should have a route to the
other subnet. A host in 135.88.128.0 net should have a routing entry that
specifies the destination address of 135.88.64.0 using its own IP address as a
gateway to the 135.88.64.0 net. The bridge/router’s interface address should
not be used as a gateway to another subnet, since the bridge does not
understand IP routing.). </p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>With the simple topology of figure 2.1, we can easily
capture initial Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs) before each bridge is
engaged in the spanning tree calculation.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
<u>set the IP address</u> of an interface in the bridge/router, go to the
console of the router/bridge and enter the privileged-level by typing enable.
Type <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>configure</b> to begin
configuration mode. In the configuration mode, to specify an interface and
start interface configuration, enter <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>interface</b>
<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>interface_type interface_number</i>. For
example, type <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>interface ethernet 0</b>
to configure the ethernet0 interface. Note that the prompt has changed to:
router1(config-if)#, router2(config-if)# or router3(config-if)#, respectively.
From the interface configuration mode, use the “<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ip address</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>address net_mask</i>”
command to set the IP address of that interface (ethernet 0).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
<u>configure the transparent bridge</u>, the following steps are needed in the
configuration mode. (<b><u>Note</u></b>: as mentioned above typing “?” at any
prompt will give you a list of all possible commands that you can input at that
level!)</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo17;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>To bridge (as opposed to route) IP datagrams, disable
IP routing: <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>no ip routing</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo9;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Define the spanning-tree protocol: <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>bridge</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>group</i> <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>protocol</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>protocol</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo17;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>To choose an interface type:<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>interface ethernet 0 </b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>or</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>
interface Ethernet 1</b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo17;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Assign the network interfaces to a spanning-tree group:<b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> bridge-group </b><i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>group</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l7 level1 lfo17;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]><span style='mso-bidi-font-style:italic'>To bring an
interface up (if in shutdown mode) type: <b>no shutdown</b></span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- the argument <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>group</i> is a number between one and nine
that you choose to refer to a particular set of bridged interfaces. Frames are
bridged only among interfaces in the same group.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- <i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>protocol</i> specifies the protocol to use.
It can be either <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ieee</b> for the ieee
spanning-tree protocol, or <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>dec</b> for
DEC spanning-tree protocol.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l8 level1 lfo18;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Set the spanning-tree parameters, if necessary:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Select the
route bridge using priority;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Adjust the
interval between HELLO Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs);</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Define the
forward delay interval;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Define the
maximum idle interval;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Assign path
costs;</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.25in'>- Set an
interface priority</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>To
set the above parameters, you must configure the bridge. The following is an
example of a basic bridge configuration (IP addressing and transparent
bridging, i.e., no routing) on router1. Type the following (in this order) at
the router_name(config)# prompt on the screen:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>no ip routing</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>bridge 1
protocol ieee </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>interface
ethernet 0</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>ip address
135.88.129.1 255.255.192.0</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>bridge-group 1</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>no shutdown</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>interface
ethernet 1</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>ip address
135.88.129.2 255.255.192.0</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>bridge-group 1</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;text-indent:.5in'>no shutdown</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Exit
configuration mode using "Ctrl-z". Save your configuration using <b>write</b>
and check your configuration using <b>write terminal</b>. For more information,
refer to the bridge manual at Cisco’s online web site. After configuring
transparent bridging as in figure 2.1 and table 2.1, do the following
experiments.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 1</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Configure the IP addresses of
your PCs and the routers as shown in figure 2.1 and table 2.1. You can use <b>tethereal
–V</b> on both machines for immediate detailed output. Use <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>tethereal –V > /</b><i><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>tmp/ex1.txt</span></i>
on your machine and <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>tethereal –V > /</b><i><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>tmp/ex1.txt</span></i><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> </b><span style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>on a machine on the other
network segment concurrently to save your <b>tetherea</b>l output to a file for
further analysis. To see the output on the screen run <b>tethereal –V </b>in
another window. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>From one machine send <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b> messages to the other machine
using the command, <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping </b><i
style='mso-bidi-font-style:normal'>other</i>_<i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>machine</i>. After receiving the tenth echo reply, quit the <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>ping</b> process. </p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Questions #1</u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span>Answer
the following questions:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What is the subnet address of the network in figure
2.1?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What will happen when the IP address of one of the PCs
is changed to: 135.88.130.101 and we try to ping to it from the <i>other_machine</i>?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>When a packet is sent to a PC in the other segment, do
the source and destination Ethernet addresses; change? Why?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What are the IP and link-layer addresses of a packet
that goes from <i>your_machine</i> to the bridge?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>What are the IP and link-layer addresses of a packet
from the bridge to the <i>other_machine</i>?</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='margin-left:.25in;text-align:justify;text-indent:
-.25in;mso-list:l3 level1 lfo35;tab-stops:list .25in'><![if !supportLists]><span
style='font-family:Symbol'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Answer the same questions, but for the echo reply that
is returned from the <i>other_machine</i>.</p>

<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:20.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-font-kerning:14.0pt;mso-ansi-language:
EN-US;mso-fareast-language:EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all
style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

<h1><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>L</span>ab # 2 Part 2 <!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span><span style="mso-spacerun:
yes"> </span>TC "Chapter 1" \f C \l "1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]-->- Experiments for the 4th Week<span
style='font-weight:normal'> </span><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-element:field-begin'></span></span><span
style="mso-spacerun: yes"> </span>TC "<span style='font-weight:normal'>Experiments
for the 3rd Week</span>" \f C \l "1" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='font-weight:normal'><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span></span><![endif]--><span
style='font-weight:normal'><o:p></o:p></span></h1>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>Read Ch 2.1.7 for this set of experiments</span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>.<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;mso-list:none;tab-stops:.5in'>Objectives</h2>

<h2 style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in;mso-list:l14 level1 lfo37;
tab-stops:list .5in'><![if !supportLists]><span style='font-family:Symbol;
font-weight:normal'>·<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>       
</span></span><![endif]>Spanning Tree Algorithm<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.1	Objective" \f C \l
"2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><span style='font-size:12.0pt;
mso-bidi-font-size:10.0pt;font-family:Times;mso-fareast-font-family:"Times New Roman";
mso-bidi-font-family:"Times New Roman";mso-ansi-language:EN-US;mso-fareast-language:
EN-US;mso-bidi-language:AR-SA'><br clear=all style='page-break-before:always'>
</span></b>

<h2><![if !supportLists]>1.3<span style='font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>        
</span><![endif]>Spanning Tree Algorithm<!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-begin'></span> TC "3.4	Spanning Tree
Algorithm" \f C \l "2" <![endif]--><!--[if supportFields]><span
style='mso-element:field-end'></span><![endif]--></h2>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>In
this section, we will use figure 2.2 as our network topology. Refer to section
1.2 on how to configure a bridge. You may want to create a table with the
physical addresses of all the devices to facilitate your work in this section.
The subnet mask is 255.255.255.0. For the bridges use IP addresses:
135.88.75.104 – 111 (i.e. host numbers 104, 105, 106 ….111 keeping the subnet
ID at 135.88.75).</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<br style='mso-ignore:vglayout' clear=ALL>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>            </span>Upon
being initiated, a transparent bridge learns the network topology by analyzing
the source address of incoming frames from all attached networks. The next
exercise shows the process by which a transparent bridge builds a transparent
bridging table.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3>(One recommendation: note down the ethernet MAC addresses
for each interface as you will be using them a lot for the next exercises and
labe reports.</p>

<p class=MsoBodyText3><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 1</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Run <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>tethereal –V </b>on the 4 PCs. The packets marked IEEE 802.3 are the
BPDU messages generated by the bridges. <b>Tethereal</b> parses the BPDUs.
Examine the packets and observe who is sending them (note some are loopback
packets). Remember, if you want to save your tethereal output, use the”> <i>filename</i>”
command<i>.</i></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Below is the BPDU table
identifying the different fields. Using <b>tcpdump</b> <b>–i </b>eth0<b> -p</b>
<b>–ex</b> one can see all the fields too but you have to translate the hex
output.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 2</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>After configuring the network in
figure 2.2, move to the router console. Go to the privileged-prompt mode. Type <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>show bridge</b> to see the entries in the
bridge forwarding database.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>When you <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>ping</b> or <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>telnet</b> to the
host that is not in the table, observe how the forwarding database is expanded.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>You may need to <b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>clear bridge</b> <i style='mso-bidi-font-style:
normal'>group</i> command to remove any learned entries from the table.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Transparent bridges exchange the
configuration information in the form of Bridge Protocol Data Units (BPDUs).
When the bridge is powered up and whenever a topology change is detected, the
spanning-tree calculation occurs, based upon exchanged BPDU information. The
BPDU format is shown below:</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<div align=center>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>protocol identifier 0<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>version 0<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>message type 0<o:p></o:p></b></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>flags</b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>    </span>The least significant
bit (Topology Change bit) is set to signal a topology change. The most
significant bit is to acknowledge receipt of a BPDU with the TC bit set. The
remaining six bits are not used.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>root ID</b> identifies the root bridge by listing its 2-byte priority
followed by its 6-byte ID (ethernet address). We can set the value of the
2-byte priority in the configuration mode. Thus the bridge can be selected as
the root bridge. The default priority is 128.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>root path cost</b> The cost of the path from the bridge sending the
configuration message to the root bridge. This cost is related to the cost of
each interface. The default cost for ethernet interface is 100, which we can
change. Usually the cost of interface is inversely proportional to the speed of
the attached network.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>bridge ID</b> identifies the priority and IC of the bridge sending the
message.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>port ID</b> The first byte is the priority value of an interface, which
is configurable. The default value of this port priority is 0. The second byte
is assigned by the bridge to the port from which the BPDU was sent. This field
is used to detect the situation when a bridge has two ports attached on a loop.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>message age</b><span class=MsoFootnoteReference> </span>(in 1/256ths of
a second) indicates when the spanning tree topology is recalculated if a bridge
does not hear BPDUs from the root bridge. The default value is 15 seconds.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>hello time</b> (in 1/256ths of a second) provides the time period
between BPDUs from the root bridge. The default value is 1 second.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'>forward</b> <b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>delay</b> (in
1/256ths of a second) provides the amount of time that bridges should wait
before transiting a port from blocking to forwarding. If a bridge transitions
too soon, not all network links may be ready to change their state, and loops
can result. The default value is 30 seconds.</p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'><u>Exercise 3</u></b><span style='mso-tab-count:1'>       </span></p>

<p class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify'>Using<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
normal'> tethereal –V or tcpdump –i </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'>eth0</span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'> –p -ex</b>, capture the BPDU packet
flowing on your network segment and the other network segments. Login to each
bridge (or use the console) and collect the outputs of the <b>show </b><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>interface </b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'>command, </span><b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>show bridge</b><span
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:bold'> command, and show </span><b
style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'>spanning-tree</b><span style='mso-bidi-font-weight:
bold'> command</span>.<b style='mso-bidi-font-weight:normal'><u><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

normal'><u><![if !supportEmptyParas]> <![endif]><o:p></o:p></u></b></p>

normal'><u>Questions #1 </u></b>:<span style="mso-spacerun: yes">  </span></p>

 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l14 level1 lfo37;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Draw the spanning tree as seen by the bridges.
     Include all relevant output data to justify your solution, give a network
     diagram identifying all the MAC addresses and how they fit into the

 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l14 level1 lfo37;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Identify the root ports, designated ports, and
     blocking ports. </li>
 <li class=MsoNormal style='text-align:justify;mso-list:l14 level1 lfo37;
     tab-stops:list .5in'>Identify who is sending the BPDUs related to the
     spanning tree protocol (i.e., the non loopback packets) on each segment. </li>
</ul>
